Description: Terracotta figure of indeterminate sex holding a cow or ram (?), probably a votary. Fragment of hand-made arms of devotee and the animal only. From a figure with a hollow wheel-made body and applied details (arms and animal). Buff clay fabric. Body and head of figure missing.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Wheel-made Cypriot figures of both male and female devotees occasionally hold such animal offerings. They are dated to the 6th or late 6th century BC to the early 5th century BC (Karageorghis 1995, 52, cat. no. 47; pl. XXVI:6, I(viii)19; 1998, XXX). Similar examples found at Lapethus, Cyprus (British Museum GR1900,0903.11, GR1900,0903.20; Karageorghis 1998, 59, cat. no. 14; pl. XXXVII:2). Parallels from the Heraion of Samos (Schmidt 1968, 51, T1961, T1913, T1799), part of Schmidt 's group 4, were dated 600BC-560BC, though recent re-dating by Henke (2011, 219; 2013 pers.comm) suggest this group may date to the 7th century BC. Karageorghis, V. 1998. 'The Coroplastic Art of ancient Cyprus. V. The Cypro-Archaic Period Small Female Figurines A. Handmade / Wheelmade Figurines'. Nicosia. Karageorghis, V. 1995. 'The coroplastic art of ancient Cyprus. IV. The Cypro- Archaic period. Small male figurines'. Nicosia.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DA.033) (Phase 3)
